request_pathways.name: Authorization for Release of Health Information
Mail completed authorization to Health Information Management Services

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients download a generic Authorization for Release of Health Information PDF, fill it out, and mail it to Health Information Management Services; MyChart is mentioned as an alternative.

red_flags: No electronic submission path for general (non-radiology) authorization requests — mail or in-person delivery only
bright_spots: Spanish-language version linked directly from Medical Records page
Fillable PDF with 39 interactive fields and documented accessibility remediation
Clear patient rights section stating authorization is voluntary with revocation instructions
Separate opt-in for sensitive record categories (substance abuse, mental health, HIV/AIDS, genetic testing) with California statute citations
Helpful parenthetical examples for each record type to aid patient understanding

findability.rationale: Level 5: Prominently available with minimal effort — first web search surfaced the PDF directly, and the Medical Records page clearly links both English and Spanish versions with no barriers.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Fillable PDF allows digital completion, but general (non-radiology) requests require printing and mailing to a physical address; fax/email available only for radiology requests.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized 2-page form with logical flow, clear instructions, and helpful record-type examples; minor issues include a typo ('specifcally') and spelling errors in the Spanish version.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the generic ROI authorization form but it was not designed for patient self-access — the patient must fill in both source and recipient fields to authorize release to themselves, with no mention of HIPAA Right of Access.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: No notarization or in-person requirements; fees disclosed on website at compliant levels ($0.25/page, $25 electronic); voluntary authorization and revocation rights clearly stated; minor gap is no response-time commitment or fee disclosure on the form itself.

overall.summary: UCSF Medical Center provides an easily findable, well-designed fillable authorization form in two languages, but lacks a dedicated patient access pathway and requires mail submission for general requests.
